book_summary.overall_summary:
Venture Deals is a practical, experience-driven guide to how venture capital financing actually works, written to demystify the opaque language, incentives, and documents that govern startup financings. The authors open by mapping the human ecosystem — entrepreneurs, angels, lead VCs, syndicates, lawyers, and advisors — and explain how those players’ motivations shape both the economic outcomes and control provisions in every financing. Using historical anecdotes (like the DEC/AR&D story) and clear framing, they present the term sheet as the decisive junction of economics (who gets what) and control (who makes which decisions).

From that framing the book walks readers clause-by-clause through a modern term sheet: valuation mechanics, liquidation preferences and participation, option-pool math, anti-dilution protections, board composition, protective provisions, conversion mechanics, and the practical meaning of registration, information, and transfer rights. Interleaved with this legal and financial tour are repeated entrepreneur-focused sidebars that translate investor priorities into founder tradeoffs and negotiation tactics — what to fight for, what to accept, and how to create leverage (e.g., by creating competitive processes and choosing the right lead investor).

The authors then shift from term-sheet clauses to the concrete bookkeeping and alternate instruments that matter: a deep, worked walkthrough of capitalization tables (pre- and post-money math, option-pool effects, and rounding pitfalls) and a careful treatment of convertible debt (notes), caps, discounts, and SAFE/KISS alternatives — including the risks these instruments can create if misused. A practical legal chapter follows, highlighting recurring founder mistakes (employment terms, PIIAs/IP assignment, 83(b) elections, corporate form) and offering preventive hygiene entrepreneurs should prioritize before taking investment.

Finally, the book steps back to a macro view of startup communities (the Boulder Thesis), arguing that ecosystems succeed through long-term, entrepreneur-led commitment, inclusive activity, and persistent practice. Across the book the tone remains pragmatic and tactical: it equips founders and emerging investors with the vocabulary, math, and negotiation instincts to structure deals that align incentives, preserve upside, and reduce catastrophic surprises.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 1, "The Players," maps the human and institutional landscape that shapes every venture deal. Building on the Introduction's framing of the term sheet as the artful junction of economics and control, this chapter introduces the core participants — the entrepreneur who brings the opportunity and carries most execution risk; the venture capitalist who evaluates, structures and syndicates investments; and the angel investor who often supplies early capital and mentorship. It explains financing-round nomenclature (seed, Series A, B, etc.), distinguishes types of venture firms (traditional institutional funds, micro-VCs, corporate VCs) and describes syndication dynamics: how leads set terms, how others join, and why a well-chosen lead changes negotiation leverage and term-sheet content.

The chapter also highlights the professional support ecosystem — lawyers who translate business deals into enforceable documents and mentors/advisors who add noncapital value — and points out how each player’s incentives influence eventual economic and control provisions. By clarifying roles, motivations and typical behaviors, Chapter 1 prepares the reader to understand later, more technical chapters: how investor type and syndicate structure feed directly into valuation, liquidation preferences, board composition, protective provisions and other term-sheet mechanics discussed in depth later in the book.

Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.

chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 6 shifts the book’s focus from what a term sheet is (Chapters 4–5) to what an entrepreneur should do when faced with one. Its central practical warning is simple but critical: if a term sheet contains a no‑shop clause, insist that key employment and other material terms be spelled out before you sign it. Because a no‑shop restricts your ability to solicit other offers, signing it without clarity can leave you effectively locked into negotiations while important items remain vague. The chapter underscores that a term sheet can feel like a commitment even when many specifics remain unresolved, and that those unresolved specifics are the very things that most affect founders’ lives and incentives.

If you care about information rights for your shareholders, you are nuts. You
should run a transparent organization as much as possible in the twenty-first

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 7 reframes the term-sheet conversation from the entrepreneur’s vantage point, arguing that entrepreneurs should embrace transparency rather than fear investor information rights. Building on the book’s earlier framing of the term sheet as the decisive document, the chapter counsels founders that if they cannot commit to sharing a budget and regular financial statements, they should not take outside capital. At the same time, it recognizes that sensible founders who are naturally cautious can and should require strict confidentiality protections around sensitive disclosures.

Practically, the chapter recommends negotiating information rights that satisfy investor needs without surrendering operational control or exposing proprietary details. It positions routine reporting as part of running a modern, well-managed company and as a prerequisite for outside investment, while advising founders to pair disclosure obligations with confidentiality clauses and clear limits to avoid unnecessary administrative burden or competitive harm. The entrepreneur’s perspective, therefore, is to proactively manage information flows rather than resist them, using the term sheet to set expectations and guardrails.

Chapter 8 reframes the negotiation playbook from the entrepreneur’s point of view: prioritize the items that drive upside and future exit value rather than getting bogged down in secondary transactional details like registration rights. Building on the book’s earlier framing of the term sheet as the decisive document, the chapter advises founders to think forward to exit scenarios (especially an IPO) and to structure deals so that founder economics and upside participation are protected. Practical guidance includes focusing energy on liquidation preferences, participation/convertible terms, anti‑dilution protections, option pool sizing, and control provisions that can materially dilute or cap founder returns — and being willing to de‑emphasize or trade away registration rights if doing so improves economic or governance outcomes.

The chapter also connects to earlier tactical advice: it complements Chapter 6’s admonition to insist on spelling out material employment terms before conceding exclusivity and Chapter 7’s argument for transparent information flows. Entrepreneurs are urged to embrace transparency and cooperative investor relationships to smooth the path to an IPO — because if an IPO is likely, registration rights become less central and the world is good. The takeaway is a practical prioritization: secure upside and exit‑enabling terms first, view registration rights as negotiable secondary protections, and structure the term sheet to align investor incentives with the company’s path to a public offering.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 9 shifts to the entrepreneur’s vantage, taking a pragmatic look at the restriction on sales clause—commonly called the right of first refusal (ROFR) on common stock—and explains why founders should generally accept it. The chapter defines typical ROFR language, explains that the clause is easier to manage if placed in the company bylaws (so it’s centralized and hard to miss), and traces how historical attitudes shifted: early VC orthodoxy often blocked founder sales until investor liquidity, but the rise of secondary markets and longer liquidity horizons changed practice. Rather than viewing ROFR as an onerous investor grab, the chapter argues it’s useful for controlling the shareholder base, helping the company and existing shareholders by vetting transfers and giving the company notice and options when insiders seek to sell.

The chapter also offers practical guidance consistent with earlier negotiation advice: entrepreneurs should support ROFRs but be precise about their scope. Limit ROFR benefits to defined “major investors” (and be explicit about who qualifies), or condition transferee ROFRs on continued participation in future financing rounds. The authors recommend putting the restriction in the bylaws to avoid fragmentation across many documents, and note the broader regulatory context—the SEC’s increased scrutiny—making control and transparency around transfers even more important.

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. The chapter stresses that founders must understand cap table math because ownership percentages, dilution effects, option pools, and share pricing all flow from these calculations and directly affect the economic and control outcomes of a deal.

The chapter also warns about rounding and fractional-share issues—intermediate rounding can produce material discrepancies—so entrepreneurs should verify the math themselves rather than rely entirely on counsel. Finally, it emphasizes the practical uses of the cap table: analyzing term sheets, explaining dilution to the board, and negotiating adjustments like option-pool size.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

Chapter 13 turns from priced equity rounds (Chapters 11–12) to an alternative seed instrument: convertible debt (notes). It explains that convertible debt is structurally a loan that typically converts into the next equity round at a discounted price (rewarding early risk). The chapter walks through the mechanics entrepreneurs should insist on (reasonable time horizon to a financing, forced conversion if the horizon passes, and floors on conversion valuation) and warns that leaving debt outstanding can give noteholders disproportionate leverage over a struggling company.

The authors unpack key economic and legal features: discounts, valuation caps (which cap the conversion price and protect early investors when the next round prices very high), conversion mechanics (qualified financing thresholds, maturity periods, automatic conversion language, and amendment/majority-consent traps), and warrants (how warrant coverage is calculated, exercise terms, merger treatment, and original-issue-discount accounting issues). They contrast early-stage (seed/bridge) use of notes with later-stage bridge financings, and present SAFEs/KISSes as non-debt alternatives—simpler in some ways but with trade-offs (no maturity, weaker investor leverage, and missing default pro-rata rights). The chapter emphasizes how these choices affect future negotiations, cap tables (Chapter 12), and investor relations (Chapter 11), and urges entrepreneurs to negotiate caps/terms thoughtfully and to be careful about disclosing seed note terms to prospective VCs.

Building on the earlier, clause-by-clause and balance-sheet level discussions (term sheets, cap tables, convertible notes, and legal hygiene), this chapter steps back to the macro question: why do some places produce and sustain startups while others don’t? It summarizes three disciplinary explanations—economic agglomeration (external economies), sociological, and geographic accounts—and then proposes a fourth, practice-driven model called the Boulder Thesis. The Boulder Thesis argues the health of a startup community rests on four practical components: entrepreneur-led leadership, long-term commitment, inclusivity, and continual activities that engage the full entrepreneurial stack.

The chapter emphasizes the temporal and practical implications of those components. Leaders must commit for the long haul (the author suggests a mental horizon of ~20 years) because startup ecosystems go through recurring economic cycles and only long-term, persistent effort yields durable clusters. A vibrant community emphasizes inclusive, activity-based engagement—hackathons, meetups, accelerators, and startup weekends—that create repeated, tangible interactions across first-time founders, experienced entrepreneurs, investors, mentors, employees, and service providers. The community should tolerate trial and error: some activities will fail, some will endure, but the ongoing experimentation and inclusive participation are what sustain momentum.

data.overall_summary:
Venture Deals is a practical, experience-driven guide to how venture capital financing actually works, written to demystify the opaque language, incentives, and documents that govern startup financings. The authors open by mapping the human ecosystem — entrepreneurs, angels, lead VCs, syndicates, lawyers, and advisors — and explain how those players’ motivations shape both the economic outcomes and control provisions in every financing. Using historical anecdotes (like the DEC/AR&D story) and clear framing, they present the term sheet as the decisive junction of economics (who gets what) and control (who makes which decisions).

From that framing the book walks readers clause-by-clause through a modern term sheet: valuation mechanics, liquidation preferences and participation, option-pool math, anti-dilution protections, board composition, protective provisions, conversion mechanics, and the practical meaning of registration, information, and transfer rights. Interleaved with this legal and financial tour are repeated entrepreneur-focused sidebars that translate investor priorities into founder tradeoffs and negotiation tactics — what to fight for, what to accept, and how to create leverage (e.g., by creating competitive processes and choosing the right lead investor).

The authors then shift from term-sheet clauses to the concrete bookkeeping and alternate instruments that matter: a deep, worked walkthrough of capitalization tables (pre- and post-money math, option-pool effects, and rounding pitfalls) and a careful treatment of convertible debt (notes), caps, discounts, and SAFE/KISS alternatives — including the risks these instruments can create if misused. A practical legal chapter follows, highlighting recurring founder mistakes (employment terms, PIIAs/IP assignment, 83(b) elections, corporate form) and offering preventive hygiene entrepreneurs should prioritize before taking investment.

Finally, the book steps back to a macro view of startup communities (the Boulder Thesis), arguing that ecosystems succeed through long-term, entrepreneur-led commitment, inclusive activity, and persistent practice. Across the book the tone remains pragmatic and tactical: it equips founders and emerging investors with the vocabulary, math, and negotiation instincts to structure deals that align incentives, preserve upside, and reduce catastrophic surprises.

Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals

This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 4, "Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet," sets the stage for the practical core of the book by explaining why the term sheet matters and by situating it historically (the DEC/AR&D anecdote) and conceptually. The authors argue that although modern term sheets have grown into multi-page legal documents, the real negotiation always comes down to two axes: economics (who owns what) and control (who makes the big decisions). The chapter also introduces and clarifies the human and institutional cast involved in financings — from the different roles inside a VC firm to angels, syndicates, and lawyers — and outlines the fundraising process entrepreneurs should expect (materials, demos, due diligence, timing, and creating competitive processes).

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.

The authors distill VC concerns into two overarching priorities—economics and control—and then walk through the common economic and governance provisions that implement those priorities. The chapter stresses that valuation is only one piece of the economics puzzle and that other clauses (liquidation preference, pay-to-play, option pool sizing, warrants, vesting, antidilution, etc.) materially affect founder and investor outcomes. chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 6 shifts the book’s focus from what a term sheet is (Chapters 4–5) to what an entrepreneur should do when faced with one. Its central practical warning is simple but critical: if a term sheet contains a no‑shop clause, insist that key employment and other material terms be spelled out before you sign it. Because a no‑shop restricts your ability to solicit other offers, signing it without clarity can leave you effectively locked into negotiations while important items remain vague. The chapter underscores that a term sheet can feel like a commitment even when many specifics remain unresolved, and that those unresolved specifics are the very things that most affect founders’ lives and incentives.

The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you care about information rights for your shareholders, you are nuts. You

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 7 reframes the term-sheet conversation from the entrepreneur’s vantage point, arguing that entrepreneurs should embrace transparency rather than fear investor information rights. Building on the book’s earlier framing of the term sheet as the decisive document, the chapter counsels founders that if they cannot commit to sharing a budget and regular financial statements, they should not take outside capital. At the same time, it recognizes that sensible founders who are naturally cautious can and should require strict confidentiality protections around sensitive disclosures.

Practically, the chapter recommends negotiating information rights that satisfy investor needs without surrendering operational control or exposing proprietary details. It positions routine reporting as part of running a modern, well-managed company and as a prerequisite for outside investment, while advising founders to pair disclosure obligations with confidentiality clauses and clear limits to avoid unnecessary administrative burden or competitive harm. The entrepreneur’s perspective, therefore, is to proactively manage information flows rather than resist them, using the term sheet to set expectations and guardrails.

Balancing transparency with protection of sensitive information
Operational expectations tied to accepting outside investment

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 8 reframes the negotiation playbook from the entrepreneur’s point of view: prioritize the items that drive upside and future exit value rather than getting bogged down in secondary transactional details like registration rights. Building on the book’s earlier framing of the term sheet as the decisive document, the chapter advises founders to think forward to exit scenarios (especially an IPO) and to structure deals so that founder economics and upside participation are protected. Practical guidance includes focusing energy on liquidation preferences, participation/convertible terms, anti‑dilution protections, option pool sizing, and control provisions that can materially dilute or cap founder returns — and being willing to de‑emphasize or trade away registration rights if doing so improves economic or governance outcomes.

The chapter also connects to earlier tactical advice: it complements Chapter 6’s admonition to insist on spelling out material employment terms before conceding exclusivity and Chapter 7’s argument for transparent information flows. Entrepreneurs are urged to embrace transparency and cooperative investor relationships to smooth the path to an IPO — because if an IPO is likely, registration rights become less central and the world is good. The takeaway is a practical prioritization: secure upside and exit‑enabling terms first, view registration rights as negotiable secondary protections, and structure the term sheet to align investor incentives with the company’s path to a public offering.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 9 shifts to the entrepreneur’s vantage, taking a pragmatic look at the restriction on sales clause—commonly called the right of first refusal (ROFR) on common stock—and explains why founders should generally accept it. The chapter defines typical ROFR language, explains that the clause is easier to manage if placed in the company bylaws (so it’s centralized and hard to miss), and traces how historical attitudes shifted: early VC orthodoxy often blocked founder sales until investor liquidity, but the rise of secondary markets and longer liquidity horizons changed practice. Rather than viewing ROFR as an onerous investor grab, the chapter argues it’s useful for controlling the shareholder base, helping the company and existing shareholders by vetting transfers and giving the company notice and options when insiders seek to sell.

The chapter also offers practical guidance consistent with earlier negotiation advice: entrepreneurs should support ROFRs but be precise about their scope. Limit ROFR benefits to defined “major investors” (and be explicit about who qualifies), or condition transferee ROFRs on continued participation in future financing rounds. The authors recommend putting the restriction in the bylaws to avoid fragmentation across many documents, and note the broader regulatory context—the SEC’s increased scrutiny—making control and transparency around transfers even more important.

chapter_summaries.summary:
This short chapter brings a practical, entrepreneur-focused set of chores to the forefront: protect the company by getting proprietary information and inventions agreements (PIIAs) signed by everyone on the team — founders included — before taking outside financing, and be prepared to negotiate limited carve-outs for unrelated outside work. It frames these agreements as standard, company-protecting documents that prevent later ownership and confidentiality disputes, and recommends resolving any legitimate pre-existing work-in-progress exceptions up front with investors.

Building on the book’s earlier negotiation framing, the chapter then addresses the co‑sale/right‑of‑first‑refusal regime from a pragmatic angle: you probably won’t eliminate co‑sale rights entirely, but you should ask for reasonable floors and exclusions so small, bona fide founder liquidity events (for example, selling a bit of stock to buy a house) aren’t blocked. It reiterates the acceptability of a ROFR that permits purchase at the valuation in a bona fide outside offer while warning against broad “effective exclusions” that swallow founder flexibility. The thrust is balance: protect IP and company value while negotiating sensible limitations on investor transfer controls to preserve founder practicality and morale.

The Entrepreneur's Perspective

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 11 continues the entrepreneur-focused thread from earlier chapters by walking through several standard but often glossed clauses in a venture term sheet and explaining why, in most cases, founders should accept them rather than fight. The chapter opens with a blunt practical warning about founders' activities clauses: if you cannot agree to such restrictions, traditional VC financing is unlikely to be successful unless you negotiate narrow carve-outs and accept likely tradeoffs (for example, changes to vesting or IP ownership). The bulk of the chapter then treats three boilerplate provisions—no-shop agreements, indemnification, and assignment—explaining their purpose, typical language, and pragmatic ways founders should approach them.

The treatment of no-shop provisions emphasizes process and relationships over pure legal bargaining: use a reasonably short timebound (30–60 days), require reciprocity in the VC’s commitment to close, and test the lead's seriousness before locking yourself in. Indemnification is presented as essentially unavoidable today; founders should expect to indemnify directors and investors to the fullest extent permitted by law and plan to secure D&O insurance (more common after Series A). The assignment clause simply preserves a VC firm’s internal flexibility to move positions among affiliated funds, but entrepreneurs should insist that any transferee agree in writing to be bound by the same financing agreements and avoid loopholes that transfer rights without corresponding obligations.

The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. That's why most cap tables have two addi- tional significant digits (or fractional shares)-the rounding to the nearest share doesn't happen during intermediate steps but only at the very end. As the entrepreneur, you shouldn't blindly rely on legal counsel to generate these documents. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. Although some get it right, it's your responsibility as the entrepreneur to make sure you understand your cap table. chapter_summaries.summary:
After the clause-by-clause tour through a term sheet in previous chapters, Chapter 12 turns to the practical bookkeeping that ties those clauses together: the capitalization table (cap table). The cap table is the numerical map of who owns what before and after a financing and is almost always summarized in the term sheet. The chapter stresses that founders must understand cap table math because ownership percentages, dilution effects, option pools, and share pricing all flow from these calculations and directly affect the economic and control outcomes of a deal.

Using a concrete example (2,000,000 founder shares, $10M pre-money, $5M investment, and a 20% post-money option pool), the chapter walks through the steps to solve for total shares outstanding, the number of shares in the option pool, the number of preferred shares issued to the VC, and the preferred price per share. It shows how a post-money option pool requirement (20%) reduces founders from 100% to 46.67% ownership and produces a post-money cap table where the VC owns 33.33%. The chapter also warns about rounding and fractional-share issues—intermediate rounding can produce material discrepancies—so entrepreneurs should verify the math themselves rather than rely entirely on counsel. Finally, it emphasizes the practical uses of the cap table: analyzing term sheets, explaining dilution to the board, and negotiating adjustments like option-pool size.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

Chapter 13 turns from priced equity rounds (Chapters 11–12) to an alternative seed instrument: convertible debt (notes). It explains that convertible debt is structurally a loan that typically converts into the next equity round at a discounted price (rewarding early risk). The chapter walks through the mechanics entrepreneurs should insist on (reasonable time horizon to a financing, forced conversion if the horizon passes, and floors on conversion valuation) and warns that leaving debt outstanding can give noteholders disproportionate leverage over a struggling company.

The authors unpack key economic and legal features: discounts, valuation caps (which cap the conversion price and protect early investors when the next round prices very high), conversion mechanics (qualified financing thresholds, maturity periods, automatic conversion language, and amendment/majority-consent traps), and warrants (how warrant coverage is calculated, exercise terms, merger treatment, and original-issue-discount accounting issues). They contrast early-stage (seed/bridge) use of notes with later-stage bridge financings, and present SAFEs/KISSes as non-debt alternatives—simpler in some ways but with trade-offs (no maturity, weaker investor leverage, and missing default pro-rata rights). The chapter emphasizes how these choices affect future negotiations, cap tables (Chapter 12), and investor relations (Chapter 11), and urges entrepreneurs to negotiate caps/terms thoughtfully and to be careful about disclosing seed note terms to prospective VCs.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Building on the earlier, clause-by-clause and balance-sheet level discussions (term sheets, cap tables, convertible notes, and legal hygiene), this chapter steps back to the macro question: why do some places produce and sustain startups while others don’t? It summarizes three disciplinary explanations—economic agglomeration (external economies), sociological, and geographic accounts—and then proposes a fourth, practice-driven model called the Boulder Thesis. The Boulder Thesis argues the health of a startup community rests on four practical components: entrepreneur-led leadership, long-term commitment, inclusivity, and continual activities that engage the full entrepreneurial stack.

The chapter emphasizes the temporal and practical implications of those components. Leaders must commit for the long haul (the author suggests a mental horizon of ~20 years) because startup ecosystems go through recurring economic cycles and only long-term, persistent effort yields durable clusters. A vibrant community emphasizes inclusive, activity-based engagement—hackathons, meetups, accelerators, and startup weekends—that create repeated, tangible interactions across first-time founders, experienced entrepreneurs, investors, mentors, employees, and service providers.
